docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Cry of Muslim Women for Equal Rights Is Rising (front page, March 9): Let us not forget that divorce, homelessness, spousal abuse, teen-age pregnancy and rape are rampant in the United States. So before we blame any Muslim country's legal system, let us acknowledge that such things exist in the non-Muslim world and often go unreported.
docs.abstract: Saulat Pervez letter on Mar 9 article on drive for women's rights in Muslim societies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After telling a judge that she was ''truly sorry'' for her ''terrible mistake,'' a 20-year-old Brooklyn woman was sentenced yesterday to probation and community service for manslaughter in the asphyxiation of her baby minutes after she secretly gave birth. The woman, Karlie DiTrapani, an unmarried former college student, delivered the baby boy in a bathroom of the Canarsie home she shared with her mother, sister and brother in December 1996. Until then she had kept the pregnancy a secret from her family and virtually all of her friends.

headline.main: Woman Is Given Probation In Death of Baby Born in Secret

docs.abstract: Justice Albert Tomei sentences Karlie DiTrapani to probation and community service in the death of the baby she delivered to herself in secret in the bathroom of her home in Brooklyn in December 1996; prosecutors said she asphyxiated the newborn by wrapping him in a towel and plastic bag and putting the bundle in a drawer of her bedroom dresser; defense argued that baby was was already dead from fatal lung infection; Tomei convicted her of manslaughter, rejecting murder charges (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oh, to be 25 again, right? If you're any distance beyond that age of infinite possibility, ''Significant Others,'' a new drama that has its premiere tonight on Fox, will leave you with a twinge of envy. But you'll surely savor what you've gained with experience as well. This appealing tease of a show was thought up by Amy Lippman and Christopher Keyser, the creators of the award-winning ''Party of Five,'' which has nobly tracked a family of orphans through a thicket of serious issues: teen-age pregnancy, alcoholism, the ravages of cancer.

headline.main: Prime Time: Starting Out In L.A. at 25

docs.abstract: Will Joyner reviews new Significant Others, new Fox show that focuses on three people starting adulthood in Los Angeles (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVOLUTION is usually viewed as pushing women toward monogamy. The idea is that a man who is sure he is the father of a child will be more likely to help out around the jungle, or the house. But a study of the Bari people of Venezuela shows that promiscuity sometimes works better than fidelity. Under a concept called partible paternity, said Dr. Stephen Beckerman, an anthropology professor at Pennsylvania State University, the man who initiates a pregnancy is considered the primary father of the child, and any lover taken by the woman during her pregnancy becomes a secondary father with the serious obligation of supplying the child with extra protein. The Bari mostly eat manioc plants, which provide calories but too little protein to support the healthy growth of children. Secondary fathers who fish and hunt provide extra protein to their children through gifts of extra food.
docs.abstract: Study of Bari people of Venezuela finds that among couples, promiscuous women raise healthier children than those that practice fidelity; study finds that any lover taken by a woman during pregnancy becomes a secondary father with serious obligation of supplying child with extra protein (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON Oct. 15, Diane S., a 30-year-old woman who lives in Grand Rapids, Mich., faced what might be her last chance to become pregnant. In two and a half years, she had spent tens of thousands of dollars on fertility treatments and could not afford to try much longer. Her doctor had created five healthy embryos by mixing Diane's eggs with her husband's sperm. The doctor could put two or three embryos into her uterus, freezing the rest for later, or he could put them all in. If the doctor put in all five embryos, she might have a better chance of becoming pregnant, he told her. On the other hand, she might have twins or triplets. If he froze some embryos, she might have another chance for a pregnancy. But, that would mean paying for the freezing and storage, another $1,000 or so, and paying for another cycle at the clinic. And the embryos might not survive thawing. What did she want him to do?

headline.main: Harrowing Choices Accompany Advancements in Fertility

docs.abstract: Issue of potential multiple pregnancies is becoming vexing problem for couples seeking fertility treatment, with agonizing emotional issues at stake; potential for twins, triplets and more babies has become dilemma that is far from unusual as more and more couples turn to in vitro fertilization, and as increasing numbers of fertility clinics fiercely compete for patients; fertility experts confess that their field has gone astray with built-in incentives for creating pregnancies involving twins, triplets and more; they say they are hoping to solve problem through technology, finding ways to increase odds that embryos they implant will survive, making it unnecessary to implant several embryos to create a pregnancy; two fertility experts, Dr Richard Berkowitz of Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Dr Mark Sauer of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, comment; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN she was 5 years old, Yolanda Suarez Merchant and her family fled Cuba and moved to Miami, then to rural Iowa, and then to Southampton, N.Y. Miss Merchant described her childhood in Southampton this way: ''It was mostly farmers and my mother in her Chanel suit.'' Her family was Old World -- formal, close-knit and religious. Miss Merchant wore white gloves to school even as a teen-ager, and her dates were chaperoned until she went away to boarding school at 16.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARIE PUSATERI was six months pregnant when she walked into an interview a few weeks ago for a job as an Internet communications manager in Manhattan. ''I declined the receptionist's offer to take my coat, preferring to carry it in front of me,'' Ms. Pusateri said. ''If I had a house plant I would have carried that, too.'' She needn't have bothered. When Ms. Pusateri confessed to the interviewer that she was expecting, the executive said: ''No problem. I'm pregnant, too.''

headline.main: Yes, I'll Take a Seat, And the Job Offer, Too

docs.abstract: Question of applying for job while obviously pregnant discussed; Federal law forbids discrimination against pregnant women, and data show vast majority do remain on the job, but discrimination by interviewers is hard to prove; photo (S)
